strlib.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*
00002  * File: strlib.h
00003  * Version: 1.0
00004  * Last modified on Fri Jul 15 14:10:40 1994 by eroberts
00005  * -----------------------------------------------------
00006  * The strlib.h file defines the interface for a simple
00007  * string library.  In the context of this package, strings
00008  * are considered to be an abstract data type, which means
00009  * that the client relies only on the operations defined for
00010  * the type and not on the underlying representation.
00011  */
00012 
00013 /*
00014  * Cautionary note:
00015  * ----------------
00016  * Although this interface provides an extremely convenient
00017  * abstraction for working with strings, it is not appropriate
00018  * for all applications.  In this interface, the functions that
00019  * return string values (such as Concat and SubString) do so
00020  * by allocating new memory.  Over time, a program that uses
00021  * this package will consume increasing amounts of memory
00022  * and eventually exhaust the available supply.  If you are
00023  * writing a program that runs for a short time and stops,
00024  * the fact that the package consumes memory is not a problem.
00025  * If, however, you are writing an application that must run
00026  * for an extended period of time, using this package requires
00027  * that you make some provision for freeing any allocated
00028  * storage.
00029  */
00030 #ifndef STRLIB_H_
00031 #define STRLIB_H_
00032 #include <iostream>
00033 
00034 /*
00035  * Function: Concat
00036  * Usage: s = Concat(s1, s2);
00037  * --------------------------
00038  * This function concatenates two strings by joining them end
00039  * to end.  For example, Concat("ABC", "DE") returns the string
00040  * "ABCDE".
00041  */
00042 
00043 char* Concat(char* s1, char* s2);
00044 
00045 /*
00046  * Function: IthChar
00047  * Usage: ch = IthChar(s, i);
00048  * --------------------------
00049  * This function returns the character at position i in the
00050  * string s.  It is included in the library to make the type
00051  * string a true abstract type in the sense that all of the
00052  * necessary operations can be invoked using functions. Calling
00053  * IthChar(s, i) is like selecting s[i], except that IthChar
00054  * checks to see if i is within the range of legal index
00055  * positions, which extend from 0 to StringLength(s).
00056  * IthChar(s, StringLength(s)) returns the null character
00057  * at the end of the string.
00058  */
00059 
00060 char IthChar(char* s, int i);
00061 
00062 /*
00063  * Function: SubString
00064  * Usage: t = SubString(s, p1, p2);
00065  * --------------------------------
00066  * SubString returns a copy of the substring of s consisting
00067  * of the characters between index positions p1 and p2,
00068  * inclusive.  The following special cases apply:
00069  *
00070  * 1. If p1 is less than 0, it is assumed to be 0.
00071  * 2. If p2 is greater than the index of the last string
00072  *    position, which is StringLength(s) - 1, then p2 is
00073  *    set equal to StringLength(s) - 1.
00074  * 3. If p2 < p1, SubString returns the empty string.
00075  */
00076 
00077 char* SubString(char* s, int p1, int p2);
00078 
00079 /*
00080  * Function: CharToString
00081  * Usage: s = CharToString(ch);
00082  * ----------------------------
00083  * This function takes a single character and returns a
00084  * one-character string consisting of that character.  The
00085  * CharToString function is useful, for example, if you
00086  * need to concatenate a string and a character.  Since
00087  * Concat requires two strings, you must first convert
00088  * the character into a string.
00089  */
00090 
00091 char* CharToString(char ch);
00092 
00093 /*
00094  * Function: StringLength
00095  * Usage: len = StringLength(s);
00096  * -----------------------------
00097  * This function returns the length of s.
00098  */
00099 
00100 int StringLength(char* s);
00101 
00102 /*
00103  * Function: CopyString
00104  * Usage: newstr = CopyString(s);
00105  * ------------------------------
00106  * CopyString copies the string s into dynamically allocated
00107  * storage and returns the new string.  This function is not
00108  * ordinarily required if this package is used on its own,
00109  * but is often necessary when you are working with more than
00110  * one string package.
00111  */
00112 
00113 char* CopyString(char* s);
00114 
00115 /* Section 2 -- String comparison functions */
00116 
00117 /*
00118  * Function: StringEqual
00119  * Usage: if (StringEqual(s1, s2)) ...
00120  * -----------------------------------
00121  * This function returns TRUE if the strings s1 and s2 are
00122  * equal.  For the strings to be considered equal, every
00123  * character in one string must precisely match the
00124  * corresponding character in the other.  Uppercase and
00125  * lowercase characters are considered to be different.
00126  */
00127 
00128 bool StringEqual(char* s1, char* s2);
00129 
00130 /*
00131  * Function: StringCompare
00132  * Usage: if (StringCompare(s1, s2) < 0) ...
00133  * -----------------------------------------
00134  * This function returns a number less than 0 if string s1
00135  * comes before s2 in alphabetical order, 0 if they are equal,
00136  * and a number greater than 0 if s1 comes after s2.  The
00137  * ordering is determined by the internal representation used
00138  * for characters, which is usually ASCII.
00139  */
00140 
00141 int StringCompare(char* s1, char* s2);
00142 
00143 /* Section 3 -- Search functions */
00144 
00145 /*
00146  * Function: FindChar
00147  * Usage: p = FindChar(ch, text, start);
00148  * -------------------------------------
00149  * Beginning at position start in the string text, this
00150  * function searches for the character ch and returns the
00151  * first index at which it appears or -1 if no match is
00152  * found.
00153  */
00154 
00155 int FindChar(char ch, char* text, int start);
00156 
00157 /*
00158  * Function: FindString
00159  * Usage: p = FindString(str, text, start);
00160  * ----------------------------------------
00161  * Beginning at position start in the string text, this
00162  * function searches for the string str and returns the
00163  * first index at which it appears or -1 if no match is
00164  * found.
00165  */
00166 
00167 int FindString(char* str, char* text, int start);
00168 
00169 /* Section 4 -- Case-conversion functions */
00170 
00171 /*
00172  * Function: ConvertToLowerCase
00173  * Usage: s = ConvertToLowerCase(s);
00174  * ---------------------------------
00175  * This function returns a new string with all
00176  * alphabetic characters converted to lower case.
00177  */
00178 
00179 char* ConvertToLowerCase(char* s);
00180 
00181 /*
00182  * Function: ConvertToUpperCase
00183  * Usage: s = ConvertToUpperCase(s);
00184  * ---------------------------------
00185  * This function returns a new string with all
00186  * alphabetic characters converted to upper case.
00187  */
00188 
00189 char* ConvertToUpperCase(char* s);
00190 
00191 /* Section 5 -- Functions for converting numbers to strings */
00192 
00193 /*
00194  * Function: IntegerToString
00195  * Usage: s = IntegerToString(n);
00196  * ------------------------------
00197  * This function converts an integer into the corresponding
00198  * string of digits.  For example, IntegerToString(123)
00199  * returns "123" as a string.
00200  */
00201 
00202 char* IntegerToString(int n);
00203 
00204 /*
00205  * Function: StringToInteger
00206  * Usage: n = StringToInteger(s);
00207  * ------------------------------
00208  * This function converts a string of digits into an integer.
00209  * If the string is not a legal integer or contains extraneous
00210  * characters, StringToInteger signals an error condition.
00211  */
00212 
00213 int StringToInteger(char* s);
00214 
00215 /*
00216  * Function: RealToString
00217  * Usage: s = RealToString(d);
00218  * ---------------------------
00219  * This function converts a floating-point number into the
00220  * corresponding string form.  For example, calling
00221  * RealToString(23.45) returns "23.45".  The conversion is
00222  * the same as that used for "%G" format in printf.
00223  */
00224 
00225 char* RealToString(double d);
00226 
00227 /*
00228  * Function: StringToReal
00229  * Usage: d = StringToReal(s);
00230  * ---------------------------
00231  * This function converts a string representing a real number
00232  * into its corresponding value.  If the string is not a
00233  * legal floating-point number or if it contains extraneous
00234  * characters, StringToReal signals an error condition.
00235  */
00236 
00237 double StringToReal(char* s);
00238 
00239 #endif
